abstract.text: 11 SARS-CoV-2, the newly identified human coronavirus causing severe pneumonia 12 epidemic, was probably originated from Chinese horseshoe bats. However, direct 13 transmission of the virus from bats to humans is unlikely due to lack of direct contact, 14 implying the existence of unknown intermediate hosts. Angiotensin converting enzyme 15 2 (ACE2) is the receptor of SARS-CoV-2, but only ACE2s of certain species can be 16 utilized by SARS-CoV-2. Here, we evaluated and ranked the receptor-utilizing 17 capability of ACE2s from various species by phylogenetic clustering and sequence 18 alignment with the currently known ACE2s utilized by SARS-CoV-2. As a result, we 19 predicted that SARS-CoV-2 tends to utilize ACE2s of various mammals, except 20 murines, and some birds, such as pigeon. This prediction may help to screen the 21 intermediate hosts of SARS-CoV-2. 22 23 2 Keywords: SARS-CoV-2; coronavirus; angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2); 24 receptor utilization; phylogenetic analysis. 25 26

body_text.text: In December 2019, a novel human coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, was detected in the city 28
The aa sequences of ACE2s of Homo sapiens (human), Rhinolophus sinicus (Chinese 100 horseshoe bat), Paguma Larvata (civet), Sus scrofa (swine) and Mus musculus (mouse) 101

were downloaded from UniProt Knowledgebase; the rest of 248 vertebrate species were 102 downloaded from GenBank (File S1). Multiple sequence alignment was performed for 103 the whole aa sequences of ACEs using MAFFT with a local alignment strategy FFT-104 NS-2. The phylogenetic tree was constructed by MEGA7 using the neighbor-joining 105 (NJ) method with 1,000 bootstrap replicates and visualized using FigTree. 106

The critical aa sites for the utilization by SARS-CoV-2 were selected by picking the 108 unique aa residues in mouse ACE2 which distinct from human ACE2 and the sites 109 reported to be critical for the receptor binding of SARS-CoV in the previous study [14] . 110
body_text.section: Marking of utilizing capability by SARS-CoV-2 107

body_text.text: The initial mark for every ACE2 was 100 and the substitution on each critical sites 111 resulted in a reduction of its mark of 50 (for substitutions reported to abolish the 112 receptor binding of SARS-CoV) or 10 (for other substitutions). The utilizing capability 113 by SARS-CoV-2 of the ACE2s were ranked by the final scores and ACE2s with scores 114 >50 were considered to be potentially utilized by SARS-CoV-2. 115 116
body_text.section: Marking of utilizing capability by SARS-CoV-2 107

body_text.text: To evaluate the homology of ACE2s in different species, we built a phylogenetic tree 118 haboring ACE2s of 250 vertebrate species (Figure S1 ). The tree was branched two 119 major groups. The first group included the classes of Mammalia, Aves and Reprilia, and 120 the second group included the classes of Amphibian, Chondrichthyes and Teleostomi. 121

This tree indicated that besides mammalia, ACE2s of aves and reprilia were more likely 122 to be utilized by SARS-CoV-2 than other vertebrates. As shown in Figure 1 , among 123 mammals, human ACE2 was clustered with bat, civet and swine ACE2s but not mouse 124 ACE2, matching the previous report about the utilizing capability by SARS-CoV-2 of 125 these ACE2s. Intriguingly, cat, pangolin, cow and goat ACE2s were also clustered with 126 human ACE2. Considering the widespread of stray cats, wildlife markets and stock 127 farms in Wuhan, it was not strange that these animals could serve as potential 128 intermediate hosts of SARS-CoV-2. Indeed, it was reported in the local news that 129 SARS-CoV-2 was detected in pangolins, though further verification is required. 130

We further tried to predict the receptor utilizing capability by SARS-CoV-2 via 131 looking into the critical single aa polymorphism in different ACE2s. We screened the aa 132 sites critical for SARS-CoV-2 utilization by two approaches. First, it has been proved 133 that human, Chinese horseshoe bats, civet and swine ACE2s can be utilized by SARS-134

CoV-2 but mouse ACE2 cannot [6]. We aligned the aa sequence of these five ACE2s 135 (File S2). Eleven aa residues distinct in mouse ACE2 but conserved in other ACE2s 136 were identified, which were T20, Y83, S218, A246, K353, P426, T593, N636, A714, 137 R716 and A774. However, according to the complex structure of human ACE2 and the 138 receptor binding domain (RBD) in SARS-CoV-2 S protein (PDB ID: 6VW1), only 139 three of the eleven sites are located near the interface and potentially mediate the 140 binding, which were T20, Y83 and K353 (Figure 2A) Combining the two screening, we got nine critical aa sites as shown in Figure 2B . 148 Based on these sites, we established a marking system to evaluate the utilizing 149 capability by SARS-CoV-2 of different ACE2s. In the system, the initial score for every 150 ACE2 was 100 and substitution on the critical sites would result in reduction of 50 151 marks (for K31D, Y41A, Y83F, K353H/A/D, D355A and R357A) or 10 marks (for 152 other substitutions). K31T and Y41H would not reduce the scores since these two 153 substitutions exist in civet and Chinese horseshoe bat ACE2s, respectively ( Figure 2B) . 154 A final score less than 0 was adjusted to 0. As the result, a final score equal to or less 155 than 50 means that the ACE2 contains either at least one substitution that will abolish 156 the receptor binding or at least five other substitutions that will make it quite different 157 from human ACE2. Therefore, the ACE2s with final scores higher than 50 were 158 considered to be potentially utilized by SARS-CoV-2, while those with scores less or 159 equal to 50 were unlikely to be utilized by SARS-CoV-2. The final scores for all ACE2s 160 we analysed were listed in Table S1 . As shown in Table 1 , excluding the animals 161 unlikely contacted by people in Wuhan, pangolin, cat, cow, buffalo, goat and sheep 162 ACE2 were ranked as the top mammals that could be potentially used by SARS-CoV-2, 163 while murine ACE2s, such as mouse and rat ACE2s, got the lowest scores. As for birds, 164 pigeon ACE2 reached the highest score of 70 ( Table 1) were unlikely to be utilized by SARS-CoV-2. To verify the robustness of our ranking 172 system, we labelled the utilizing capability of different ACE2s on the phylogenetic tree, 173 and found that the ACE2s confirmed or potential to be utilized by SARS-CoV-2 174 (labelled with circles) were obviously clustered from those unlikely to be utilized by 175 SARS-CoV-2 (labelled with triangles) (Figure 1) . The well matching with the 176 phylogenetic tree elevated the liability of this marking system. 177

In summary, we combined phylogenetic analysis and critical site marking to 178 predict the utilizing capability of ACE2s from different animal species by SARS-CoV-179 2. The results from these two analysis matched each other quite well, indicating relative 180 reliability of our prediction. We have shown that, besides currently confirmed ACE2s 181 utilized by SARS-CoV-2, pangolin, cat, cow, buffalo, goat, sheep and pigeon ACE2s were downloaded from GenBank as follows: Capra hircus (AHI85757.1), Ovis aries 258 Table S1 . SARS-CoV-2 utilizing scores of all species analysed in this study. 290

FIGREF0.text: of Wuhan, China, and then the virus caused a severe epidemic of Coronavirus Disease 29 2019 (COVID-19) in China and worldwide, critically threatening the public health [1, 30 2]. The epidemic has caused 80,813 confirmed infections with 3,073 fatal cases in 31 China by March 7th, 2020, surpassing any former coronavirus epidemics. Even worse, 32 this virus emerges a worldwide spread currently and COVID-19 cases increased more 33 rapidly than China in many countries around the world, including South Korean, Iran, 34 Japan, Italy, Germany, France and United States. The interquartile deviation of the 35 infection incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 2-7 days, but the maximum can be as 36 long as 24 days according to the current reports, which is longer than other human 37 coronaviruses and exacerbates the epidemic. The typical clinical symptoms of COVID-38 19 include fever, dry cough, dyspnea, headache, and pneumonia. Finally, COVID-19 39 may result in progressive respiratory failure due to alveolar damage and even death [CoV-2 is an enveloped non-segmented positive sense RNA viruses 42 classified into the Sarbecovirus subgenus of the genus Betacoronavirus in the subfamily 43

FIGREF1.text: 81 In this study, we combined the phylogenetic analysis and critical site 82 comparison of ACE2 to predict the intermediate hosts of SARS-CoV-2. First, we 83 collected the aa sequences of ACE2s of 250 species and built a phylogenetic tree to 84 cluster the ACE2s based on their evolutionary distance. In the tree, the ACE2s of 85 species close to Chinese horseshoe bats, civet or swine but far from mouse were more 86 likely to be utilized by SARS-CoV-2. Second, we aligned the aa sequences of ACE2s of 87 Chinese horseshoe bats, civet, swine and mouse to identify the sites critical for SARS-88 CoV-2 utilization; then we ranked the ACE2s of other species according to their aa 89 substitution on these sites. The top hits were selected to be the candidates potentially 90 utilized by SARS-CoV-2. Combining the results obtained by the two methods and 91 considering the common animals living in Wuhan, we predicted pangolin, cat, cow, 92 buffalo, goat, sheep and pigeon as the potential intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2, 93 together with civet or swine. These results may help the screening for the intermediate 94 hosts of SARS-CoV-2, contributing to the study of the viral transmission and

FIGREF2.text: Second, SARS-CoV-2 shares an 141 identity of 74.6% with SARS-CoV in the aa sequences of their RBDs, and thus the aa 142 residues critical for the receptor binding of SARS-CoV may be also critical for SARS-143 CoV-2. According to the previous study, such critical sites include K31, Y41, K68, 144 Y83, K353, D355, R357 and M383 [14]. Among these sites, K31D, Y41A, Y83F, 145 K353H/A/D, D355A and R357A abolish or strongly inhibit SARS-CoV binding, while 146 the substitutions on K68 and M383 slightly inhibit SARS-CoV binding [14, 15]. 147

FIGREF3.text: Though birds are not natural 165 reserviors for currently know species of betacoronavirus, the classification of 166 coronaviruses is based on the genome feature not the host range, and thus we could not 167 exclude the possibility that new betacoronavirus may infect birds. Considering pigeons 168 are common food in Wuhan, more attention should be paid on the non-mammalian 169 hosts of SARS-CoV-2. ACE2 of Protobothrops mucrosquamatus (pallas pit viper), a 170 common snake existing in Wuhan, got a score of 20, indicating that reprilia ACE2s 171

Considering the widespread 184 of these animals in Wuhan, some of them might serve as intermediate hosts for SARS-185 CoV-2, which called for the attention in disease control. However, these are still 186 preliminary results predicted by sequence analysis which cannot accurately reflect the 187 infection in the animals, and more laboratory and epidemiological investigation are 188 required to uncover the true intermediate hosts of SARS-CoVwas jointly funded by the National Key Research and Development Program 192 of China (grant number 2017YFD0500104), National Natural Science Foundation of 193 China (grant number 31470260 and 81902070), the Science Fund for Distinguished 194 Young Scholars of Hunan Province (grant number 2019JJ20004), the Provincial Natural 195 Science Foundation of Hunan Province (grant number 2019JJ50035) and the 196 Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China (grant number 197 531107051162

TABREF0.text: Orthocoronavirinae, together with other severe acute respiratory syndrome-related 44 coronaviruses (SARSr-CoVs), such as SARS-CoV[6]. Occasional interspecies 45 transmission of virus is believed to be a major cause of coronavirus epidemic. SARS-46CoV-2 has a high genetic relationship with a bat coronavirus (BatCoV RaTG13) with a 47 96% genomic nucleotide sequence identity. The close phylogenetic relationship to Bat 48RaTG13 provides evidence for a bat origin of SARS-CoV-2 [6]. However, direct 49 transmission of the virus from bats to humans is unlikely due to the lack of direct 50 contact between bats and humans in Wuhan, China. Hence, there are probably 51 intermediate hosts transmitting SARS-CoV-2 to humans. This speculation is supported 52 by the reports about the intermediate hosts of other human coronaviruses. For instance, 53 SARS-CoV, the coronavirus causing SARS epidemic in 2003, was also originated from 54 bats [7, 8], but it transmitted to human via a variety of intermediate hosts including 55 masked palm civet cats and raccoon dogs [9, 10]. Since native reservoir hosts of viruses 56 usually live far away from human community, intermediate hosts play critical roles in 57 transmitting viruses to human and causing epidemics. A common way to determine the 58 intermediate hosts is to collect all animals in the original epidemic area and detect the 59 virus in them one by one, which is quite time-and labor-consuming and also is easy to 60 be biased by passive contamination of the samples. 61 Receptor recognition is an important factor determining host range and cross-62 species infection of viruses. Angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) has been proved 63 to be the cellular receptor of SARS-CoV-2 [6]. ACE2 was initially identified as an 64 exopeptidase expressed in vascular endothelial cells in the heart and the kidney that 65 catalyses the conversion of angiotensins [11, 12]. Later, ACE2 was well known for its 66 function as the virus receptor of SARS-CoV [13]. Utilization of ACE2 as the receptor 67 by SARS-CoV-2 is an important rationale to classify SARS-CoV-2 to the same 68 subgenus as SARS-CoV. ACE2 is expressed in most vertebrates, but not all ACEs can 69 be utilized by SARS-CoV-2 as the receptor. Currently studies demonstrated that SARS-70 CoV-2 is able to use Chinese horseshoe bats, civet, swine but not mouse ACE2 as its 71 entry receptor [6]. Obviously, the utilizing capability of ACE2 by SARS-CoV-2 can be 72 used for quick screening to narrow down the range of the intermediate hosts for SARS-73CoV-2. We intended to predict the utilizing capability by SARS-CoV-2 of different 74ACE2s via amino acid (aa) sequence comparison. Unfortunately, the aa identities 75 between human ACE2 and ACE2s of Chinese horseshoe bats, civet, swine and mouse, 76
